Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Precision Array for Probing the Epoch of Reionization (PAPER)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is for continuation of the development of the Precision Array to Probe the Epoch of Reionization (PAPER). The focus of PAPER is the statistical detection of HI 21-cm signals from the neutral intergalactic medium (IGM) during cosmic reionization, an event corresponding to the transition from a fully neutral IGM to a highly ionized IGM caused by the UV radiation from the first stars and supermassive black holes. Probing this last unexplored phase of cosmic evolution has been called out by the Astro2010 Decade Survey as the primary area with extraordinary discovery potential in the study of cosmic structure formation, and this constitutes the main intellectual impact of this research.

During the previous award period, under AST-0804508 and AST-0804523, PAPER established observing sites with 32 antenna elements at both NRAO Green Bank and in the Karoo Desert of South Africa. The current proposal will expand the SA deployment of PAPER to 128 elements and will support on-going observations and analysis using both the GB and SA deployments.

Broader impacts of the program include advancement of techniques in low frequency radio astronomy, and a strong educational emphasis through training of graduate students and postdocs. The project is a major stepping stone toward a future Hydrogen Epoch of Reionization Array (HERA), as recommended by A2010. PAPER has directed fabrication funds where possible to local small businesses, thus providing economic stimulus in the US. Outreach activities have included a number of public talks on the project by graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The long-term objective of this area of research is to address important questions such as “What were the first objects to light up the Universe, and when did they do it?” These questions, posed by the Astrophysics Decadal Survey, New Worlds, New Horizons in Astronomy and Astrophysics in 2010, are among the most fundamental and timely in astrophysics today, and mark a transformative moment or epoch in the history of the Universe.

The evolution of Hydrogen traces the evolution of the early universe and the presence or absence of hydrogen can be probed using radio techniques. However, the challenge of this measurement is not the detection of the weak hydrogen signal itself but the fact that it emanates from behind the other natural signals in the Universe that can be up to a million times stronger. This is analogous to standing at the doorway of a large room filled with people engaged in lively conversation while attempting to listen in on two individuals whispering near the center of the room.

The primary goal of this NSF grant for the Precision Array for Probing the Epoch of Reionization (PAPER) was to learn how to conduct this challenging measurement. In order to measure the hydrogen signal one must somehow separate the characteristics of this signal from that produced by the cacophony of other signals. Ssystematically acquiring and carefully analyzing sky signals from the various configurations of portable antennas that make up the PAPER instrument has yielded a pathway forward. In fact, PAPER has proven to be the most sensitive instrument to date for the detection of hydrogen, yet it is not quite sensitive enough to reach that needed for a direct detection based on current models of the Universe. However, the absence of this signal at the higher level indicates that the early universe was somehow heated, most likely from X-ray sources.

Another goal of the PAPER project was to stimulate instrument development for low frequency cosmological studies. PAPER has been incredibly successful in this regard, fostering developments in rugged, low noise amplifiers, cost-effective interference shielding techniques, antennas having a very smooth beam response, and specialized computer platforms for rapid data acquisition and analysis. The results of this work carved the foundation for the next generation instrument known as the Hydrogen Epoch of Reionization Array (HERA) that is currently being deployed in South Africa. This array incorporates the methodologies of PAPER with significantly larger antennas to boost signal strength.

FInally, the broader impact of PAPER centers around educating the next generation of students via direct hands-on learning. High school, undergraduate, graduate, and post-doctoral students from the U.S. and elsewhere have actively participated in a variety of tasks associated with PAPER. It is a hallmark of diversity for which we are particularly proud. In addition, PAPER has resided at the confluence of science and engineering, spawning new ideas and innovative methodologies designed to solve a wide range of challenging problems. While the work continues toward achieving the science goal, PAPER has been an incredible success and its legacy is that of building a solid body of knowledge from which the next generation of researchers can learn.
